body: I MADE a list of the 15 best things I ate in New York City in the past year of reviewing restaurants for The New York Times. It is an accounting that comprises restaurant dishes of uncommon excellence and flavor. Together they underscore New York's place as one of the planet's best cities in which to dine out. And we'll get to them soon enough. But
title: CRITIC'S NOTEBOOK; From the File Marked '2010 Delicious'

body: New York's many forms of mass transit stumbled back to life on Tuesday, a day after fierce snow and wind knocked out much of the city's vast network of buses, trains and planes. But while some parts of the city moved toward regaining mobility, other areas barely budged. Two subway lines, the B and the Q, remained shut down, and others ran on
title: After Disruptions on Rails and at Airports, Halting Steps Toward Normal Service

body: Good evening, snow-globe city. You survived the great post-Christmas whiteout of 2010. You frolicked and/or shoveled. You made molasses-on-snow. Now, perhaps, you can relax. Unless you're trying to get home. The trains and buses and subways are still messed up. For specifics on your evening commute, see below. And while you wait, try the
title: CITY ROOM;What Happens When a Plow Gets Stuck

body: Airports and railroads limped back to life, but thousands were still stranded. Roads remained glazed and city streets choked with snow. Subways and buses ran sporadically. Power was still out for thousands. Business was bad, and there were grim tales of people snowbound for hours in cars, buses and trains. But the two-day blizzard that attacked the
title: Blizzard Ends, Leaving Trail of Disruption Along Coast

body: At 6:30 a.m. on Tuesday, crew members of a fishing charter boat sat in the passenger cabin, waiting for customers who did not come. On other, warmer Tuesdays, they could at least count on the arrival of a group of old-timers, but most of that crowd was away for the winter months. At nearby piers, other fishing boats bobbed idly. As sunlight broke
title: SHEEPSHEAD BAY JOURNAL; A Fisherman Always Welcome, and Now Missed

body: Haley Pierce, a 16-year-old junior from the Tatnall School of Delaware, won the girls' two-mile run in a meet-record 10 minutes 28.63 seconds at the 57th annual Bishop Loughlin Games at the New Balance Track and Field Center in Upper Manhattan. Lynn Strauss of State College, Pa., held the previous mark of 10:36.50, set in 1981. ''I had the meet
title: SPORTS BRIEFING | TRACK AND FIELD; Delaware Girl Sets 2-Mile Record

body: Last year, city education officials issued the Choir Academy of Harlem a death sentence. Unable to find its footing after a 2001 scandal that led to the demise of its founding organization, the famed Harlem Boys Choir, the school, along with 18 others, ''lacked the capacity to improve student performance,'' and would be closed, the city said. But
title: CITYROOM; Taking Advantage of a Reprieve, a School in Harlem Saves Itself

body: Send me your own dining questions via dinejournal@nytimes.com or Twitter.com/samsifton. Q. Recently, my wife and I left Manhattan in search of space and quiet and ended up in Fort Greene. It's a great area, with nice restaurants and awesome farmers' and flea markets. But I yearn to find those familiar locations that we adore so in the city, like
title: HEY, MR. CRITIC; Looking for Old Brooklyn? Nosh This Way

author: Toby Lyles contributed research.
body: SHOPPING online in late July, Clarabelle Rodriguez typed the name of her favorite eyeglass brand into Google's search bar. In moments, she found the perfect frames -- made by a French company called Lafont -- on a Web site that looked snazzy and stood at the top of the search results. Not the tippy-top, where the paid ads are found, but under
title: A Bully Finds a Pulpit on the Web

body: The New York City Department of Education said Thursday that up to 47 schools could be closed for poor performance, a huge increase from previous years if all remain on the chopping block. In the eight years since Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has used school closings as a cornerstone of his school reform strategy, 91 schools have been shuttered and
title: In Sharp Rise, 47 City Schools May Close Over Performance

body: WHERE were the vinyl widows on Sunday? Were they off doing yoga or out in a park enjoying the beautiful late-summer weather, or taking a break from the crates and stacks and piles of 33 r.p.m. records they share with some vinyl fanatic? Everyone knows the type. It is now a cliché. It is so much a cliché of early 21st century hipster life that the
title: THE GIMLET EYE; Getting Set To Spin

body: WALKING through the section of Bellerose, Queens, where Richard Steier lives with his wife, Gilda Hoyte-Steier, and her two sons, is like wandering through a patch of small-town America. The streets are lined with friendly-looking Capes dating to the 1920s, each topped with a small brick chimney. American flags flutter from every other porch. On a
title: HABITATS | BELLEROSE, QUEENS; Home At First Sight

body: FOR New Yorkers who don't make it out to the far western edge of Coney Island too often, Sea Gate might be more familiar as the skinny thumb of land that appears below window seats during some takeoffs from Kennedy International Airport. But getting into the neighborhood by land is another story. True to its name, Sea Gate is a gated community,
title: LIVING IN | SEA GATE, BROOKLYN; The Beach Is Never Far Away

body: SHOREHAM, N.Y. WHEN Jack Schwartz, a retired elementary school principal from Shoreham, received a dead piranha as a gift last fall, he was actually pleased. Not many people could muster much enthusiasm for a lifeless flesh-eating fish. But Mr. Schwartz practices the art of gyotaku, developed centuries ago by Japanese fishermen to serve as proof of
title: ARTS | LONG ISLAND; The Catch of the Day, Preserved on Paper

body: Mother Russia has long been ensconced in Brooklyn's Brighton Beach, feasting on pirogi, borscht and the tang of salty air reminiscent of Odessa. But her assimilated children have been planting colonies across the New York area, and one of the largest is flourishing on Staten Island. Staten Island's Russians -- even if many are really from Ukraine
title: STATEN ISLAND JOURNAL; As Russians Move In and Flourish, Resentment Follows

body: Click on Gallery to Enlarge A homeless man in an ''I NY'' shirt asleep on a bench in Staten Island. A just-married couple, cuddling on a bench in Brooklyn Ferry Park. A crowd doing yoga on the beach in the Rockaways, another crowd doing pilates by the East River, a third snapping pictures of the Brooklyn Bridge at sundown. Swimmers, slackers,
title: CITY ROOM; The Waterfront, Covered

body: THE counter in Winston Parker's hand read ''0000.'' It was 11 p.m. on a Friday night, and Mr. Parker, a doorman at the Box, a risqué cabaret and nightclub on the Lower East Side, was about to open the place up for the evening. Behind the doors, cocktail waitresses and hostesses were getting glamorous. They had entered in hoodies and jeans an hour
title: NOCTURNALIST; Until Dawn

body: The hot weather can make for an unpleasant riding experience -- a thick film of sweat being the obvious result of all but the shortest pedal -- but could it be causing flat tires as well? ''What I've been seeing is that the last couple of weeks of high heat is a lot more flats,'' said Jake Fleischmann at Roy's Sheepshead Cycle on Coney Island
title: CITY ROOM; Does Hot Weather Cause More Bike-Tire Problems?

body: Vincenzo Donnoli was 9 when his family immigrated legally to Brooklyn. He attended Erasmus Hall High School, married and divorced in Flatbush, ran a landscaping business and had five children. But at 51 he is back -- alone and jobless -- in Pomarico, the hill town in southern Italy where his father was a shepherd, as a deportee banned for life from
title: For Those Already Deported, Court Rulings Come Too Late

body: ''THAT right there is a top-neck clam,'' said a man sitting at the counter in Randazzo's in Sheepshead Bay, Brooklyn, about five minutes before noon on a weekday as the sun blazed down on Emmons Avenue outside. He was pointing at the fresh-shucked bivalve in front of him on an icy plate, perhaps 2 3/4 inches across the heavy span of its shell, its
title: CRITIC'S NOTEBOOK; Sea, Sun and Slurp

body: In the world's most diverse city, it was hailed as a milestone: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg signed an executive order in July 2008 requiring every New York City agency that dealt with the public to provide interpreters, translated documents and other language help to people who spoke little or no English. The order was supposed to help immigrant New
title: Language Help for New York Immigrants Using City Services Falls Short of Goals

body: THE BATHING SUIT STAND at Astoria Pool sells goggles for $4 and towels for $10. But the big sellers are padlocks ($7), which are required for admission to all city pools, which opened on Tuesday for the season, so that swimmers can secure their belongings in lockers. ''Locks are our best-selling item because people show up without realizing that
title: OPEN & SHUT; Chronicle of a Changing City

author: Have a tip for Nocturnalist?: nocturnalist@nytimes.com
body: The air over Sheepshead Bay in Brooklyn was so thick with fog on Wednesday evening that Capt. Bill Reddan steered his boat, the Jeanne II, by GPS, staring more intently at computer screens than at the monotonic mist that was starboard, port and everywhere between. Yet Captain Reddan, 70, a retired New York City police diver who now runs a
title: CITY ROOM; Nocturnalist; After Nightfall, A Voyage To the Bottom Of the Ocean

body: A church may be a church, and a temple a temple, but through the prism of emotion that still grips many New Yorkers almost a decade after 9/11, a mosque can apparently represent a lot of things. In the last few months, Muslim groups have encountered unexpectedly intense opposition to their plans for opening mosques in Lower Manhattan, in Brooklyn
title: Heated Opposition to a Proposed Mosque

body: Brooklyn is one of the most Democratic counties in the country. The nearly 900,000 enrolled Democrats in the borough outnumber Republicans by about eight to one. More Brooklynites left the party affiliation line on their latest Board of Elections enrollment forms blank than the 112,000 who described themselves as Republicans. Of all the members of
title: MILL BASIN JOURNAL; Brooklyn's G.O.P. Is Old Enough, but Quite a Few Members Shy of Grand

body: The police charged a 20-year-old man on Monday with strangling a Brooklyn woman and her 8-year-old daughter, who were found dead on Sunday in a bathtub in their apartment in Sheepshead Bay. The suspect, Amahal Lynch of Stanley Avenue in East New York, Brooklyn, was charged with two counts of murder. Mr. Lynch did not answers reporters' questions as
title: Arrest in Killing of Woman and Child

body: Edward R. Murrow High School in Midwood, Brooklyn, has long been one of the most popular schools in the city. Like any school, it has some shortcomings -- some say that with nearly 4,000 students, it is easy to get lost in the crowd. But it is hard to imagine calling it a failure. Until now. Parents from Murrow received a letter this week saying
title: School Letters Sent in Error Stir Concern Across City

body: SATURDAY night in the neighborhood that once gave America fever, a Brooklyn that looks to itself for employment and has little time for the glittering island to the north. A bridge rises out of it, a silver ramp, and you can see ocean beneath it, darkness running all the way to Portugal, and from there down the Mediterranean to the Middle East.
title: RESTAURANT REVIEW; South of the Moon, North of the Sea

body: NEW YORK is one big sprawling city, full of people who are proud to call themselves New Yorkers. But sometimes it seems as if that were where the sameness ended. Just try to find a taxi on Staten Island or a gas station in Manhattan and you will quickly learn that there are big differences among the boroughs. Another way to experience that
title: Got 500,000 Clams? The City Is Your Oyster

body: It was just another Saturday night on Queens Boulevard two years ago when Eddie Ellis and Gladys Corcino pulled up beside each other at a red light near 65th Street. He was headed home to Ridgewood after a night out with a buddy. She was the designated driver for a car full of rowdy friends. The ladies pulled up next to Mr. Ellis's Nissan Maxima,
title: In a Wedding Album From the City's 5 Borough Halls, Tales as Varied as the Rooms

body: WITH a spinning wheel in the attic, flintlock rifles on the walls, foot warmers at the hearth and a horse-drawn sleigh in the barn, Annette and Stuart Mont are well-equipped for 18th-century colonial farm life. Except they are living in Brooklyn in 2010. Home is an antiques-crammed pre-Revolutionary white Dutch farmhouse and barn that rise like
title: A Prewar Home, To Say the Least

body: To the Editor: Re ''Citing Hazard, New York Says Hold the Salt'' (front page, Jan. 11): It seems so obvious: the first and most important step in addressing health care in the United States is to do whatever we can to make Americans healthier so they need less care, thereby reducing the cost of the system and making more services available to all.
title: LETTERS; Will Restricting Salt Improve Health?
